newsitem.title: HONG KONG: Tokyo stocks hit by post-poll profit-taking.
newsitem.headline: Tokyo stocks hit by post-poll profit-taking.

text.p: Profit-takers hit Tokyo's bourse on Monday after a general election left the pro-business Liberal Democratic Party (LDP) without a clear majority.
The stock market's key Nikkei 225 average lost 309.35 points, or 1.43 percent, but trade was muted with many investors adopting a wait-and-see stance after Sunday's poll, brokers said.
Elswehere in Asia, Singapore's bourse lost one percent, while Bangkok, Taipei, Seoul and Sydney gained ground.
Markets in Hong Kong and Bombay were closed for holidays.
Current Japanese Prime Minister Ryutaro Hashimoto is likely to remain head of a coalition government forged through an alliance with smaller parties.
Brokers said disappointment over the lack of an LDP majority in the key Lower House sparked a sell-off in Tokyo, eroding last week's gains. The Nikkei ended at 21,302.95.
"The profit-taking was accelerated by disappointment that the Liberal Democratic Party did not win a majority," said Akihiro Naemura, strategist at Okasan Securities.
Many in the markets are concerned that yet another unwieldy coalition government could lead to friction over policies and impede Japan's already sluggish economic recovery.

"Eyes are now on what sort of coalition government will be formed and what sort of policies will be carried out," Naemura said. "Until the new government starts functioning, with economic stimulus policies strong enough to lure investors off the sidelines, the market is likely to be very quiet."
Singapore shares slid, with falls in a range of heavyweight stocks as foreign institutions continued to sell.
The benchmark Straits Times Industrials Index (STII) closed down 20.29 points, or 0.98 percent, at 2,044.23.
"Institutions are net sellers of this market," said one local broker. "They say they are looking for a time to buy but are concerned there doesn't seem to be a bottom yet."
Thai stocks rose for the fourth day, despite profit-taking by local retail investors, brokers said.
The SET index finished 0.43 point, or 0.05 percent, higher at 948.52 on thin turnover.

"The market moved in a narrow range throughout the session today as investors watched for the release of third quarter financial results of finance firms," said Virat Tippanontakul of First Asia Securities.
"Some of them were better than earlier expectations."
The Taiwan stock index ended slightly higher after moving in a narrow range, the index up 9.20 points, or 0.14 percent, to end at 6,441.15.
Seoul stocks were marginally higher after institutional selling in the afternoon erased most early gains, brokers said.
The composite index ended at 832.62, up 1.44 points, or 0.17 percent, on the day, but off an intra-day high of 844.51.

The Australian share market finished just a few points away from its record closing high after resource stocks found support on the back of a firmer copper price and another record close for the Dow on Friday.
The key market barometer, the All Ordinaries index, closed 8.2 points, or 0.35 percent, higher at 2,363.2, three points off last week's record high close of 2,366.2.
Jakarta's share index rose 2.27 points, or 0.40 percent, to close at 572.47 points after touching an intra-day low of 569.45 points in early trade.
Brokers said the market was likely to be more active on Tuesday as bargain-hunters targeted heavyweights on perceptions that prices were low.
At 1120 GMT, the dollar was trading at 112.87/2.97 yen and 1.5382/84 marks.
SIMEX Brent December futures were firmer in thin trading, supported by ongoing worries over heating oil stocks.
December last traded at $24.70 per barrel, up 17 cents from London's settlement.
Gold bullion was slightly weaker in Tokyo, closing at US$379.65/380.15, down from New York's close of US$380.10/50.
